| A gas spore:* can [fly](/wiki/Fly "Fly").
* [does not breathe](/wiki/Breathless "Breathless").
* has no limbs.
* has no head.
* is [mindless](/wiki/Mindless "Mindless").
* [does not eat](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate"). (\*)
* is neither male nor female.

* [never leaves a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless"). |                                                    |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |                                                    |
| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                | [monst.c#line302](/wiki/Monst.c#line302 "Monst.c") |

A **gas spore**, e, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack"). It is usually the first [sphere](/wiki/Sphere "Sphere") monster that a [player](/wiki/Player "Player") character will generally encounter.

A gas spore will not attack on its own, but [explodes](/wiki/Explode "Explode") in a 3x3 range centered on its square when its HP is depleted: the explosion deals 4-24 damage and [abuses](/wiki/Abuse "Abuse") [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength"), and killing the gas spore directly will also credit you for any monsters hit or killed by the explosion, including penalties for angering or killing [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful") monsters. [Instadeath](/wiki/Instadeath "Instadeath") that ignores HP, such as from deadly [poison](/wiki/Poison "Poison") or a [wand of death](/wiki/Wand_of_death "Wand of death"), does not cause the gas spore to explode.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

  - [2.1 Explosions](#Explosions)
  - [2.2 Protection racket](#Protection_racket)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [6.3 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [6.4 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

Randomly-generated gas spores are always created [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile").

A gas spore [never leaves a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless") upon death.

## Strategy

It is perfectly fine to simply avoid attacking gas spores altogether, as they are incapable of attacking you. However, other monsters may accidentally cause a gas spore explosion with ranged attacks or an attack prompted by [conflict](/wiki/Conflict "Conflict"); pets in particular will begin attacking gas spores once they are high enough level, which may endanger you if you are not similarly high-level.

The best strategy when faced with a gas spore that you can reasonably fight (or else cannot avoid) is to step back and use whatever [ranged attacks](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack") you have at your disposal - offensive [spells](/wiki/Spells "Spells"), [arrows](/wiki/Arrows "Arrows"), [darts](/wiki/Darts "Darts"), or even throwing [rocks](/wiki/Rocks "Rocks") and [junk](/wiki/Junk "Junk") weapons. If you have no other options, You can take a chance and dispatch the spore with melee attacks if no peaceful or tame monsters are nearby, or else if you any combination of 25+ HP, good [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") and a means of mitigating strength abuse.

Early-game [Healers](/wiki/Healer "Healer") can use gas spores to train their weapon skills, such as the [knife](/wiki/Knife "Knife") (via the starting [scalpel](/wiki/Scalpel "Scalpel")) or the more common [dagger](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger"), using a [stethoscope](/wiki/Stethoscope "Stethoscope") to monitor the gas spore's HP and allow it to heal back up before attacking it again. While any role can do this, Healers are the only one guaranteed to start with the stethoscope.

### Explosions

As noted above, your character is considered responsible for any damage done to monsters by a gas spore's explosion that they caused. This has a number of repercussions, depending on the monster:

- Pets killed by the gas spore explosion are treated as if you had killed them directly, i.e. -15 [alignment](/wiki/Alignment "Alignment") and -1 [luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck").
- Peaceful monsters become angry, incurring a -1 penalty to [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record"), and you incur a -5 alignment penalty if the explosion kills a peaceful monster without angering it. On top of early alignment penalties hampering your odds of survival, [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeepers "Shopkeepers"), [aligned priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest") and [watchmen](/wiki/Watchmen "Watchmen") in particular will cause you plenty of grief if you anger them.
- However, other hostile monsters can be killed by the explosion - as you gain experience for each kill, this can possibly allow you to rise a quick level or two if the opportunity arises.

Keep in mind that gas spore explosions create a loud noise which will wake [sleeping](/wiki/Sleep "Sleep") monsters. Directing gas spores into [leprechaun halls](/wiki/Leprechaun_hall "Leprechaun hall") or [barracks](/wiki/Barracks "Barracks") is a fun (if somewhat risky) maneuver.

### Protection racket

Gas spores are one of many threats to a protection racket that may warrant gaining a couple of levels prior to entering the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines"), then [level draining](/wiki/Level_drain "Level drain") yourself once you successfully reach the [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown") [temple](/wiki/Temple "Temple").

## History

The gas spore first appears in [NetHack 3.3.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0 "NetHack 3.3.0").

## Origin

The gas spore originates from *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, where it is a type of spherical floating fungus with a central false "eye" and ten rhizome growths on its top, giving it a close resemblance to the [beholder](/wiki/Beholder "Beholder") that causes it to be mistaken for the monster from a distance. The rhizome growths serve as feeding organs, and are used to extract lichen and mold from walls, leaves from trees and scum from the surface of ponds.

Gas spores are hollow, but their interiors contain a large number of spores kept under high pressure. A gas spore that is hit anywhere except the rhizome growths and damaged at all will explode, releasing poisonous gas and a large amount of spores within 20 feet of itself - it can also spread its spores by making contact with the exposed flesh of any warm-blooded creature that is at least gnome-sized, and will die immediately after doing so. Victims that a gas spore infects die if they do not obtain a cure within 24 hours - the corpse of a being that succumbs to this infection then sprouts several tiny gas spores, which reach maturity within seven days.

Gas spores that grow upon the corpses of dead beholders are known to carry the memories of their host, which a humanoid infected by the spore can access. This may be a basis for in-universe beliefs that the spores first appeared as a result of parasitic fungi that fed off dead beholders and became infected with aberrant magic, adapting the ability to quickly sprout from any infected corpse after a long period.

## Messages

- You hear a blast.

  An gas spore exploded outside of your range of vision.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), 37 gas spores are generated within the [Neutral Quest](/wiki/Neutral_Quest "Neutral Quest") at level creation, and may be among the random e that can also be generated at level creation. They share the same exact glyph as the [Beholder](/wiki/Beholder_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Beholder (SLASH'EM)"), e, which can prove deadly if you mistake it for one and fail to [blind](/wiki/Blind "Blind") yourself against its [gaze](/wiki/Gaze "Gaze") attacks.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), gas spores are created if you read a cursed or uncursed [scroll of stinking cloud](/wiki/Scroll_of_stinking_cloud "Scroll of stinking cloud") while [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused").

One type of [random vault](/wiki/Random_vault_\(UnNetHack\) "Random vault (UnNetHack)") that can be encountered is a "room with sessile growths", which may contain several gas spores.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), pets will not attack a gas spore if you are adjacent to it.

xNetHack also adds the "sessile growth" random vault as a [themed room](/wiki/Themed_room "Themed room"), and includes an additional themed room that is mostly or entirely filled with gas spores.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack") and [SpliceHack-Rewrite](/wiki/SpliceHack-Rewrite "SpliceHack-Rewrite"), a [scroll of elementalism](/wiki/Scroll_of_elementalism "Scroll of elementalism") can summon gas spores if read while confused.

## Encyclopedia entry

The attack by those who want to die  
\-- this is the attack against which you cannot prepare a perfect defense.  
                               --Human aphorism

\[ The Dosadi Experiment, by Frank Herbert ]

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Gas spore

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
e gas spore
Difficulty 2
Attacks Explode 4d6
e gas spore
Difficulty 2
Attacks

Explode 4d6

Base level 1
Base experience 12
Speed 3
Base AC 10
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 10
Nutritional value 10
Size Small
Resistances None
Resistances conveyed None

A gas spore:

  • can fly.
  • does not breathe.
  • has no limbs.
  • has no head.
  • is mindless.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is neither male nor female.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • never leaves a corpse.
Reference monst.c#line302

A gas spore, e, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is usually the first sphere monster that a player character will generally encounter.

A gas spore will not attack on its own, but explodes in a 3x3 range centered on its square when its HP is depleted: the explosion deals 4-24 damage and abuses strength, and killing the gas spore directly will also credit you for any monsters hit or killed by the explosion, including penalties for angering or killing peaceful monsters. Instadeath that ignores HP, such as from deadly poison or a wand of death, does not cause the gas spore to explode.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
    • 2.1 Explosions
    • 2.2 Protection racket
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Messages
  • 6 Variants
    • 6.1 SLASH'EM
    • 6.2 UnNetHack
    • 6.3 xNetHack
    • 6.4 SpliceHack
  • 7 Encyclopedia entry

Generation

Randomly-generated gas spores are always created hostile.

A gas spore never leaves a corpse upon death.

Strategy

It is perfectly fine to simply avoid attacking gas spores altogether, as they are incapable of attacking you. However, other monsters may accidentally cause a gas spore explosion with ranged attacks or an attack prompted by conflict; pets in particular will begin attacking gas spores once they are high enough level, which may endanger you if you are not similarly high-level.

The best strategy when faced with a gas spore that you can reasonably fight (or else cannot avoid) is to step back and use whatever ranged attacks you have at your disposal - offensive spells, arrows, darts, or even throwing rocks and junk weapons. If you have no other options, You can take a chance and dispatch the spore with melee attacks if no peaceful or tame monsters are nearby, or else if you any combination of 25+ HP, good AC and a means of mitigating strength abuse.

Early-game Healers can use gas spores to train their weapon skills, such as the knife (via the starting scalpel) or the more common dagger, using a stethoscope to monitor the gas spore's HP and allow it to heal back up before attacking it again. While any role can do this, Healers are the only one guaranteed to start with the stethoscope.

Explosions

As noted above, your character is considered responsible for any damage done to monsters by a gas spore's explosion that they caused. This has a number of repercussions, depending on the monster:

  • Pets killed by the gas spore explosion are treated as if you had killed them directly, i.e. -15 alignment and -1 luck.
  • Peaceful monsters become angry, incurring a -1 penalty to alignment record, and you incur a -5 alignment penalty if the explosion kills a peaceful monster without angering it. On top of early alignment penalties hampering your odds of survival, shopkeepers, aligned priests and watchmen in particular will cause you plenty of grief if you anger them.
  • However, other hostile monsters can be killed by the explosion - as you gain experience for each kill, this can possibly allow you to rise a quick level or two if the opportunity arises.

Keep in mind that gas spore explosions create a loud noise which will wake sleeping monsters. Directing gas spores into leprechaun halls or barracks is a fun (if somewhat risky) maneuver.

Protection racket

Gas spores are one of many threats to a protection racket that may warrant gaining a couple of levels prior to entering the Gnomish Mines, then level draining yourself once you successfully reach the Minetown temple.

History

The gas spore first appears in NetHack 3.3.0.

Origin

The gas spore originates from Dungeons & Dragons, where it is a type of spherical floating fungus with a central false "eye" and ten rhizome growths on its top, giving it a close resemblance to the beholder that causes it to be mistaken for the monster from a distance. The rhizome growths serve as feeding organs, and are used to extract lichen and mold from walls, leaves from trees and scum from the surface of ponds.

Gas spores are hollow, but their interiors contain a large number of spores kept under high pressure. A gas spore that is hit anywhere except the rhizome growths and damaged at all will explode, releasing poisonous gas and a large amount of spores within 20 feet of itself - it can also spread its spores by making contact with the exposed flesh of any warm-blooded creature that is at least gnome-sized, and will die immediately after doing so. Victims that a gas spore infects die if they do not obtain a cure within 24 hours - the corpse of a being that succumbs to this infection then sprouts several tiny gas spores, which reach maturity within seven days.

Gas spores that grow upon the corpses of dead beholders are known to carry the memories of their host, which a humanoid infected by the spore can access. This may be a basis for in-universe beliefs that the spores first appeared as a result of parasitic fungi that fed off dead beholders and became infected with aberrant magic, adapting the ability to quickly sprout from any infected corpse after a long period.

Messages

You hear a blast.
An gas spore exploded outside of your range of vision.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, 37 gas spores are generated within the Neutral Quest at level creation, and may be among the random e that can also be generated at level creation. They share the same exact glyph as the Beholder, e, which can prove deadly if you mistake it for one and fail to blind yourself against its gaze attacks.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, gas spores are created if you read a cursed or uncursed scroll of stinking cloud while confused.

One type of random vault that can be encountered is a "room with sessile growths", which may contain several gas spores.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, pets will not attack a gas spore if you are adjacent to it.

xNetHack also adds the "sessile growth" random vault as a themed room, and includes an additional themed room that is mostly or entirely filled with gas spores.

SpliceHack

In SpliceHack and SpliceHack-Rewrite, a scroll of elementalism can summon gas spores if read while confused.

Encyclopedia entry

The attack by those who want to die
-- this is the attack against which you cannot prepare a perfect defense.
                               --Human aphorism

[ The Dosadi Experiment, by Frank Herbert ]

A '''gas spore''', {{monsym|gas spore}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in [[NetHack]]. It is usually the first [[sphere]] monster that a [[player]] character will generally encounter.

A gas spore will not attack on its own, but [[explode]]s in a 3x3 range centered on its square when its HP is depleted: the explosion deals 4-24 damage and [[abuse]]s [[strength]], and killing the gas spore directly will also credit you for any monsters hit or killed by the explosion, including penalties for angering or killing [[peaceful]] monsters. [[Instadeath]] that ignores HP, such as from deadly [[poison]] or a [[wand of death]], does not cause the gas spore to explode.

==Generation==
Randomly-generated gas spores are always created [[hostile]].

A gas spore [[Corpseless|never leaves a corpse]] upon death.

==Strategy==
It is perfectly fine to simply avoid attacking gas spores altogether, as they are incapable of attacking you. However, other monsters may accidentally cause a gas spore explosion with ranged attacks or an attack prompted by [[conflict]]; pets in particular will begin attacking gas spores once they are high enough level, which may endanger you if you are not similarly high-level.

The best strategy when faced with a gas spore that you can reasonably fight (or else cannot avoid) is to step back and use whatever [[ranged attack]]s you have at your disposal - offensive [[spells]], [[arrows]], [[darts]], or even throwing [[rocks]] and [[junk]] weapons. If you have no other options, You can take a chance and dispatch the spore with melee attacks if no peaceful or tame monsters are nearby, or else if you any combination of 25+ HP, good [[AC]] and a means of mitigating strength abuse.

Early-game [[Healer]]s can use gas spores to train their weapon skills, such as the [[knife]] (via the starting [[scalpel]]) or the more common [[dagger]], using a [[stethoscope]] to monitor the gas spore's HP and allow it to heal back up before attacking it again. While any role can do this, Healers are the only one guaranteed to start with the stethoscope. 

===Explosions===
As noted above, your character is considered responsible for any damage done to monsters by a gas spore's explosion that they caused. This has a number of repercussions, depending on the monster:

* Pets killed by the gas spore explosion are treated as if you had killed them directly, i.e. -15 [[alignment]] and -1 [[luck]].
* Peaceful monsters become angry, incurring a -1 penalty to [[alignment record]], and you incur a -5 alignment penalty if the explosion kills a peaceful monster without angering it. On top of early alignment penalties hampering your odds of survival, [[shopkeepers]], [[aligned priest]]s and [[watchmen]] in particular will cause you plenty of grief if you anger them.
* However, other hostile monsters can be killed by the explosion - as you gain experience for each kill, this can possibly allow you to rise a quick level or two if the opportunity arises.

Keep in mind that gas spore explosions create a loud noise which will wake [[sleep]]ing monsters. Directing gas spores into [[leprechaun hall]]s or [[barracks]] is a fun (if somewhat risky) maneuver.

===Protection racket===
Gas spores are one of many threats to a protection racket that may warrant gaining a couple of levels prior to entering the [[Gnomish Mines]], then [[level drain]]ing yourself once you successfully reach the [[Minetown]] [[temple]].

==History==
The gas spore first appears in [[NetHack 3.3.0]].

==Origin==
The gas spore originates from ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', where it is a type of spherical floating fungus with a central false "eye" and ten rhizome growths on its top, giving it a close resemblance to the [[beholder]] that causes it to be mistaken for the monster from a distance. The rhizome growths serve as feeding organs, and are used to extract lichen and mold from walls, leaves from trees and scum from the surface of ponds.

Gas spores are hollow, but their interiors contain a large number of spores kept under high pressure. A gas spore that is hit anywhere except the rhizome growths and damaged at all will explode, releasing poisonous gas and a large amount of spores within 20 feet of itself - it can also spread its spores by making contact with the exposed flesh of any warm-blooded creature that is at least gnome-sized, and will die immediately after doing so. Victims that a gas spore infects die if they do not obtain a cure within 24 hours - the corpse of a being that succumbs to this infection then sprouts several tiny gas spores, which reach maturity within seven days.

Gas spores that grow upon the corpses of dead beholders are known to carry the memories of their host, which a humanoid infected by the spore can access. This may be a basis for in-universe beliefs that the spores first appeared as a result of parasitic fungi that fed off dead beholders and became infected with aberrant magic, adapting the ability to quickly sprout from any infected corpse after a long period.

==Messages==
{{message|You hear a blast.|An gas spore exploded outside of your range of vision.}}

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], 37 gas spores are generated within the [[Neutral Quest]] at level creation, and may be among the random {{white|e}} that can also be generated at level creation. They share the same exact glyph as the [[Beholder (SLASH'EM)|Beholder]], {{monsym|Beholder (SLASH'EM)}}, which can prove deadly if you mistake it for one and fail to [[blind]] yourself against its [[gaze]] attacks.

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], gas spores are created if you read a cursed or uncursed [[scroll of stinking cloud]] while [[confused]].

One type of [[Random vault (UnNetHack)|random vault]] that can be encountered is a "room with sessile growths", which may contain several gas spores.

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], pets will not attack a gas spore if you are adjacent to it.

xNetHack also adds the "sessile growth" random vault as a [[themed room]], and includes an additional themed room that is mostly or entirely filled with gas spores.
